instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00165: What is 820-00165? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U1950: What is U1950? This chip often becomes corroded on pin 8 on the PP3V42_G3H pin causing PM_SLP_S4_L to go missing.
definitions.U6100: What is U6100? this is an SPI ROM chip that holds the BIOS which is necessary for the machine to POST or try and power on..
definitions.C1950: What is C1950? Capacitor between PP3V42_G3H & ground on pin 8 of U1950 on 2013-2015 Macbook Pros & Airs that often corrodes. When corroded, pin 8 on U1950 will be damaged, which will prevent machine from booting and cause PM_SLP_S4_L to pulse. .

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Boot. Has 1.8V on vcore.
threads.message: This board spins up for about 5 seconds, fan dies, then spins back up. Has 1.8V on vcore after originally having 1.7V until I fixed <CHIP>U1950</CHIP> area. No chime. PRAM does nothing. No video/backlight. I attached pre-ultrasonic pics. Not sure where to go next.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Boot. Has 1.8V on vcore.
threads.message: Most likely corroded trace/resistor from <CHIP>U6100</CHIP> to the SMC. Check all traces and termination resistors from <CHIP>U6100</CHIP>.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Boot. Has 1.8V on vcore.
threads.message: Did you remove J6100??? do a continuity test on SPI lines and resistors...

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Boot. Has 1.8V on vcore.
threads.message: Yes, pulled J6100. I have continuity on all 22 of the SPI lines. Resistors are good. I see this exact issue on a lot of boards. Fan up, down, up, full vcore, but no boot.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Boot. Has 1.8V on vcore.
threads.message: <CHIP>U1900</CHIP> should be replaced and <CHIP>U1950</CHIP> replaced and if already done inspected again. Close up picture of affected area may also help.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Boot. Has 1.8V on vcore.
threads.message:
No Title

Replaced <CHIP>U1900</CHIP>. No change. All of these boards always need <CHIP>U1950</CHIP> replaced so that was replaced too.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Boot. Has 1.8V on vcore.
threads.message: <CAPACITOR>C1950</CAPACITOR> should not sit that way, is there 3V there? Trace to <RESISTOR>R1961</RESISTOR> looks sad, I know it is no stuff but trace needs to be intact, so check for continuity around <CHIP>U1950</CHIP>.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Boot. Has 1.8V on vcore.
threads.message: No change. I fixed that <RESISTOR>R1961</RESISTOR> trace. I originally thought it wouldn't matter so I was going to just leave it. <CAPACITOR>C1950</CAPACITOR> needs to go sideways on these to reach the scraped off trace when the original pad is often blown off. 3.4V is solid in that area.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Boot. Has 1.8V on vcore.
threads.message:
No Title

Ok, got it. It did end up being the <CHIP>U1950</CHIP> circuit. The <SIGNAL>PM_PCH_SYS_PWROK</SIGNAL> trace was blown at the pad I circled. It was't getting to <RESISTOR>R1962</RESISTOR>. Thanks for the help.
